name: Mortgagee Requires Possession for Sale
short_description: Mortgage lender requires possession to exercise power of sale

notice_requirement.timing: Before or at start of tenancy
notice_requirement.content: Notice must state lender may recover possession under Ground 2
notice_requirement.exception: Court may dispense if just and equitable

lender_requirement.action: Requires possession to exercise power of sale
lender_requirement.reason: Usually due to arrears or breach of mortgage terms

notice_period.court_proceedings: Can be started after notice expires

evidence_required: Mortgage deed showing date granted (before tenancy)
Written notice given at tenancy start
Letter from mortgagee stating requirement for possession
Evidence of mortgage arrears or default (if applicable)
Mortgagee's intention to exercise power of sale

high_probability: Clear written notice at tenancy start
Lender has started or threatened possession proceedings against landlord
medium_probability: Lender requirement genuine but arrears being addressed
low_probability: No notice given and court refuses to dispense
Claim appears to be landlord using lender as excuse

red_flags: No written notice given at start
tenant_defenses: No notice given and no good reason to dispense
Landlord cannot prove mortgage exists or predates tenancy
notes: Ground 2 is MANDATORY but rarely used as lenders usually seek possession directly against landlord. Often seen when landlord in financial difficulty.
case_law: Britannia Building Society v Earl [1990] - Lender can seek possession under Ground 2
National & Provincial Building Society v Lloyd [1996] - Notice requirements strictly applied
